6.4 AMOSTRAS DE SANGUE

O laboratório do estudo seguiu as normas de qualidade vigentes e exigidas (KUSCHNIR et al., 2016) . O laboratório de referênc ia fica localizado na cidade de Cascavel, Paraná, e tem uma rede de 60 laboratórios parceiros distribuídos pelos centros do ERICA. O laboratório de referência é certificado pelo Programa Nacional de Controle de Qualidade ligado à Sociedade Brasileira de An álises Clínicas e ao Programa de Acreditação de Laboratórios Clínicos que tem parceria com a Sociedade Brasileira de Patologia Clínica/Medicina Laboratorial (CUREAU et al., 2017) . Todos os estudantes foram orientados a per manecer em jejum por 12 horas na noite anterior e as coletas foram feitas no dia seguinte de manhã em jejum. Somente os alunos dos turnos da manhã foram incluídos na coleta de sangue (BLOCH et al., 2015) .
Quatro tubos foram coletados de todos os alunos que participaram da pesquisa, exceto no Rio de Janeiro, Rio Grande do Sul, Distrito Federal e Ceará. Nesses locais, dois tubos

adicionais foram coletados e armazenados para análises futuras (BLOCH et al., 2015) . Após a homogeneização, os tubos foram armazenados em caixas térmicas (0 -10C) para o laboratório local e, em seguida, para o laboratório de referência. Os tubos de gel foram centrifugados po r 10 minutos a 3.000 rpm e em seguida, resfriados. O tempo entre a coleta e a centrifugação não excedeu 2 horas. O tubo primário de flúor foi submetido ao mesmo procedimento antes da separação do plasma e transferência para o tubo de transporte. Os tubos d e EDTA foram refrigerados diretamente para manter a temperatura igual ou abaixo de 10 C. Todas as amostras com problemas antes da análise (por exemplo, hemólise) foram destruídas no próprio laboratório local. Menos de 1% (n = 273) dos participantes tinha r esultado missing . As principais razões para a falta de amostras foram quantidade insuficiente de sangue (61,2%), amostras coaguladas, hemolizada ou lipêmicas (15%) e amostras danificadas durante o transporte (14,6%). Aproximadamente 92% das amostras chegar am ao laboratório de referência com a temperatura apropriada, entre 0 e 10 C. As amostras para análise foram acondicionadas em sacos e, em seguida, em caixas térmicas com gelo seco e transportadas para o laboratório de referência por via aérea. A tempera tura foi verificada em três pontos de controle: na chegada ao laboratório local, antes do transporte e no laboratório de referência com o objetivo de manter a temperatura entre 0 a 10 C (CUREAU et al., 2017) . Os resultados de amostras fora da faixa de temperatura foram comparados com os outros na análise bruta (média e intervalos de confiança de 95%). O erro analítico aceitável por exame foi estabelecido considerando as variações biológicas e laboratoriais (CUREAU et al., 2017; MINCHINELA et al., 2014) .

Biorrepositórios locais com ultracongeladores a -80C para conservação de amostras, estrutura laboratorial adequada e profissionais treinados para realizar o preparo, separação, identificação e organiz ação das amostras foram utilizados para armazenamento de soro dos adolescentes de Rio de Janeiro, Rio Grande do Sul, Ceará e Distrito Federal para análises futuras (CUREAU et al., 2017) .

6.5 GARANTIA E CONTROLE DE QUALIDADE

O manual de operações com descrição detalhada dos procedimentos foi preparado para prevenir e minimizar erros e para garantir padronização d a coleta de dados. As equipes de campo foram treinadas e houve monitorização durante a duração do estudo.

A coordenação central do estudo treinou as equipes de campo de acordo com o protocolo de estudo. Vídeos foram produzidos para orientar as equipes de campo sobre as medidas antropométricas (BLOCH et al., 2015) . Os critério s de Habicht para medidas antropométricas foram utilizados como guia durante o treinamento que consistem no seguinte procedimento: Dez indivíduos têm suas medidas aferidas duas vezes por cada treinando para evitar que a primeira aferição influencie na segu nda. A confiabilidade -intraindividual é definida pel soma tório da diferença das duas aferições elevada ao quadrado para o mesmo antropometrista e a confiabilidade interindividual é definida pel o soma tório das diferenças elevada ao quadrado entre o treinand o e o supervisor para a mesma observação. Um treinando é considerado confiável, quando a sua confiabilidade intra -individual não excede o dobro d a confiabilidade intra -individual do supervisor. O treinando é considerado padronizado quando a confiabilidade entre indivíduos não excede o triplo da d a confiabilidade intra -individual do supervisor (FERREIRA; SICHIERI, 2007; HABICH T, 1974) .

6.7 ANÁLISE DE DADOS
As variáveis independentes utilizadas foram: obesidade, sobrepeso, circunferência da cintura e insulina.

Os métodos alternativos indiretos que representam resistência à insulina avaliados foram TyG e Tg/HDL. Optamos por não utilizar os seguin tes marcadores de resistência à insulina : HOMA -IR, FIRI, FGIR, InsuTAG e QUICKI, pois a insulina foi utilizada no modelo como variável “equivalente” e também está incluída na equação desses marcadores. Além disso, não utilizamos os marcadores de resistênc ia à insulina que t êm IMC na equação, como METS -IR e TyG -IMC, pois o IMC foi utilizado no modelo para a definição d as variáveis de obesidade e de sobrepeso e também está presente na equação desses dois marcadores.
6.7.1.1 Análise Estatística

Foram calc ulados os coeficientes de regressão linear de cada variável independente estratificada por idade e sexo. As covariáveis incluídas foram: inatividade física ( minutos por semana), tabagismo (≥1 cigarro por pelo menos dia nos últimos 30 dias ), comportam ento sedentário (≥3 /dia de uso de computador, te levisão e videogame em um dia da semana comum), consumo de álcool ( ≥ uma dose nos últimos 30 dias ), nível socioeconômico (definido por escola pública ou privada) e puberdade (estágio de Tanner de 1 Não foram feitos ajustes para comparações múltiplas como recomendado por Rothman, porque os ajustes podem reduzir o erro tipo 1 para associações nulas, mas podem aumentar o erro tipo 2 para associações que não são nulas. Em nosso estudo, como as associaçõe s avaliadas eram biologicamente plausíveis , decidimos que α não seria corrigido para multiplicidade. São associações que foram planejadas a priori e todas os resultados foram apresentados, independente mente da significância estatística (ROTHMAN, 1990) . O cálculo do equivalente de insulina em jejum (fasting insulin equivalent - FIeq) é baseado no método proposto por Sharrett, et al (SHARRETT et al., 2006) , que utilizaram equival entes de LDL para comparar a magnitude da associação de diabetes e tabagismo com aterosclerose. Esses autores calcularam o nível de concentração de LDL que replicaria o risco relativo de tabagismo e diabetes refletindo diferentes fases da história natural da enfermidade aterosclerótica (SHARRETT et al., 2006) . A padronização em unidades de LDL é justificada pelo importante papel do LDL na aterogênese e sua associação significativa com todos os
desfechos. Além disso, esse método permite fazer comparações cruzadas ent re diferentes desfechos com unidades de medidas diferentes.

Em nosso estudo, o FIeq representa o nível de insulina em jejum que replicaria a força da associação entre cada variável de adiposidade e o marcador de resistência à insulina. Seguindo o proced imento sugerido por Sharrett (SHARRETT et al., 2006) , o FIeq foi calculado pela divisão do coeficiente beta de cada fator de risco pelo coeficiente beta da insulina em jejum a partir da análise de regressão linear, estratificada por idade e sexo e ajustada por inat ividade física, tabagismo, consumo de álcool, nível socioeconômico e estágio de Tanner.
Todas as estimativas de FIeq e respectivos intervalos de confiança foram calculados pelo método jackknife. Os coeficientes de regressão (beta) foram arredondados para duas casas decimais.

A definição de Síndrome Metabólica utilizada no artigo foi a proposta pela Federação Internacional de Diabetes ( International Diabetes Federation - IDF) que identificou essa síndrome pela presença de circun ferência da cintura elevada e de dois ou mais fatores de risco, a saber: triglicerídeos elevados ≥ 150mg/dl e/ou glicose alta ≥100mg/dl e/ou HDL -c baixo <40mg/dl para meninos de 12 a 17 anos e meninas de 12 a 15 anos ou HDL -c<50mg/dl em meninas de 16 e 17 anos e/ou PA elevada ≥130/85mmHg (ALBERTI; ZIMMET, 2007) . O DM2 foi definido por diabetes diagnosticado e não diagnosticado. O diagnóstico de diabetes foi identificado se um médico disse aos participantes que eles tinham diabetes e se os participantes eram tratados para diabetes. Diabetes não diagnosticado foi definido como glicose ≥ 126md/dL ou HbA1C ≥ 6,5% e sem diabetes iden tificado por um médico (TELO et al., 2019) . Foram excluídos os participantes que relataram fazer uso de insulina classificada como diabetes tipo 1, pois o foco principal do estudo foi o DM2. Foram feitas seis combinações pareadas para avaliação das interações, sendo:1 ) HDL -c * TG; 2) TG * CC; 3) HDL -c * CC; 4) PA * CC; 5) PA * TG e 6) PA * HDL -c. Como a glicemia de jejum alterada é um forte preditor de diabetes e está incluída na definição de síndrome metabólica, decidimo s não usar o componente glicose para avaliar possíveis interações entre os componentes da síndrome metabólica e diabetes.
As interações de segunda ordem não foram avaliadas, pois, o número de casos de diabetes não foi suficiente para que o poder estatísti co (1 – β) adequado fosse alcançado.

As associações conjuntas esperadas e as observadas, foram avaliadas através de modelos de regressão de Poisson para avaliar as interações aditivas e multiplicativas entre pares de componentes da síndrome metabólica em relação a diabetes. A interação aditiva foi medida pelo Excesso Relativo de Risco (RERI) devido à interação (ROTHMAN, 1986).

Quando R RI≥0, uma interação aditiva positiva está presente. A interação multiplicativa é interpretada como associações conjuntas o bservadas divididas pela multiplicação das associações independentes. Quando razão de interação≥1, uma interação multiplicativa positiva está presente (SZKLO; NIETO, 2019a) . Deve ser enfatizado que usamos o termo “efeito(s)” ocasionalmente por seu uso ser univers al nesse contexto, mas os nossos resultados não exprime m necessariamente relação/relações causais, as quais não podem ser inferidas em estudos observacionais únicos, particularmente os transversais como o nosso.

Para cada modelo, estimamos razões de preva lência brutas e ajustadas por idade, sexo, , inatividade física (≤ 420 minutos por semana), consumo de álcool (≥1 bebida alcoólica em pelo menos um dia nos últimos 30 dias), comportamento sedentário (≥3 oras por dia gastos com televisão, videogame ou comp utador em um dia de semana normal), tabagismo (≥1 cigarro pelo menos um dia nos últimos 30 dias) e nível socioeconômico (definida pelo fato de o adolescente frequentar escolas públicas ou particulares) .

Title: Association between obesity, overweight, elevated waist circumference, and insulin resistance markers among Brazilian adolescent students1
Artigo publicado no dia 24 de agosto na revista Nutrients https://doi.org/10.3390/nu14173487

Abstract: (1) Background: There is still controversy concerning the most effective and efficient strategy to identify insulin resistance in adolescents. We estimated the level of fasting insulin (fasting insulin equivalent, FIeq) that would replicate the strength of the associations of obe sity, overweight, and waist circumference with two insulin resistance markers: triglycer -ide/high -density lipoprotein (TG/HDL) and triglyceride/glucose (TyG); (2) Methods: We studied approximately 38,000 adolescents aged 12 to 17 years, sampled from a multicenter Brazilian school -based survey, The Study of Cardiovascular Risk Factors in Adolescents (Portuguese acro -nym, ERICA), conducted in 2013 –2014. Fasting insulin equivalents for adiposity variables were calculated by dividing the beta coefficient of eac h adiposity measure by the fasting insulin beta coefficient from linear regression analysis according to age (12 –14, 15–17 years old) and sex, and adjusted by smoking, alcohol consumption, physical inactivity, sedentary behavior, socioeco -nomic status, and Tanner stage; (3) Results: The FIeqs for obesity were greater than those for overweight and elevated waist circumference for both TG/HDL and TyG in early adolescence. The FIeqs for elevated WC were greater than those for obesity and overweight in adolesce nts aged 15 to 17 years; (4) Conclusions: Our study suggests that WC measurements might be useful to identify adolescents with insulin resistance, particularly in late adolescence.

Introduction Insulin resistance in adolescents is characterized by a reduced insulin sensitivity, followed by compensatory hyperinsulinemia in order to maintain an euglycemic state [1], and it increases the likelihood of some conditions such as glucose intolerance, dyslipidemia, endothelial dysfunction, procoagulant factors, hemodynamic changes, markers of inflammation, increased testosterone secretion, and sleep -disordered breathing [2]. Thus, there is an increasing interest in the early identification of adolescents with insulin resistance in clinical routine practice [3,4]. Clinical guidelines recommend the measurement of body mass index (BMI, weight in kilograms divided by the square of height in meters) to detect obesity and overweight in primary car e settings [5]. However, previous studies have found conflicting results about the best strategy to identify insulin resistance in adolescents, that is, BMI alone, waist circumference (WC) alone, or BMI and WC [3,6,7].

The direct method for measuring insul in sensitivity, regarded as the gold standard, is the hyperinsulinemic –euglycemic clamp [8]; however, this procedure is time -consuming, expensive, invasive, and labor -intensive [8]. Indirect methods of measuring insulin resistance are typically based on in sulin and/or glucose levels, such as the homeostasis model assessment insulin resistance (HOMA -IR). Other insulin resistance markers have also gained popularity [9], including the triglyceride/high -density lipoprotein (TG/HDL) and triglyceride/glucose (TyG ) index [9]. Correlation coefficients between these markers and the hyperinsulinemic –euglycemic clamp in adolescents have been shown to be r = 0.82 for HOMA -IR, r = 0.695 for TyG index, and r = 0.416 for TG/HDL [9,10].

These insulin resistance markers are related to different aspects of glucose homeostasis and express different components of insulin resistance [11]. They also have different analytic units, which makes it difficult to compare the strength of their associations with adiposity variables. Using an LDL equivalent (based on the fact that lipids are a necessary component of atherosclerosis), Sharrett AR, et al. (2004, 2006) calculated the concentration of LDL (w ic e named “LDL equivalent”) t at would replicate t e strengt s of t e associations o f

smoking and diabetes with different phases of the natural history of atherosclerosis [12,13]. Using a similar approach, we compared obesity, overweight, and elevated WC with two insulin resistance markers. More specifically, we estimated the level of fas ting insulin (fasting insulin equivalent, FIeq) that would replicate the strength of the associations of the obesity, overweight, and elevated WC with TG/HDL and TyG. We considered fasting serum insulin levels to be a reasonable “S arrett equivalent” (i.e. , the basis for comparison), as compensatory hyperinsulinemia is the defining characteristic of insulin resistance. Thus, the aim of our study was to analyze the association between fasting insulin equivalents for adiposity variables (obesity, overweight, and elevated waist circumference) and insulin resistance markers in Brazilian adolescents.
2. Materials and Methods
2.1. Study Design and Sample

ERICA is the Portuguese acronym for The Study of Cardiovascular Risk Factors in Adolescents, a multicenter Bra zilian school -based cross -sectional survey of 75,000 adolescents aged 12 to 17 years from 1247 schools from 122 municipalities with more than 100,000 inhabitants, conducted in 2013 –2014. T e study’s multistage sampling used stratification into 32 geographi cal areas (27 State capitals and 5 macro -regions) [14,15] . The sample of 75,000 reflected the exclusion of 4 schools that refused participation, located in 2 municipalities [16]. Among the 72,508 students, a subsample of 37,815 (52.2%) morning shift adoles cents from 111 municipalities had complete information on questionnaire data, anthropometrics, and blood pressure. This subsample had their fasting blood samples collected [16].
The study was approved by local Ethics Committees [15]. More details of the s tudy design have been published [14,15] .
2.2. Anthropometric Measures

Adolescents wore light clothes and no shoes during the anthropometric measurements. Height and weight were measured by a portable calibrated stadiometer, Alturexata , and by a digital scale, model P150m, Líder , respectively [15]. The nutritional status categories were defined based on age - and sex -specific BMI levels. Obesi ty, overweight, and normal nutritional status were defined as follows: Z -score >+2; Z -score >+1 and Z -score ≤+2; Z -score ≥−2 and Z -score ≤+1, respectively [17].

WC was measured using fiberglass anthropometric tape, Sanny . As suggested by the World Health Organization, the measurement was done at the medium point between the lower costal margin and the highest point of iliac crest [15]. Values ≥90t percentile for t ose aged 10 to <16 years old, and ≥90 cm for males and ≥80 cm for females for t ose aged 16 years or older were defined as elevated WC [18].
2.3. Biochemical Assays

Only morning shift students had their bloods collected [15] and, as mentioned previously, constitute our analytic sample. All students were instructed to fast for 12 h the night befo re, and blood was collected the following morning. A detailed description of blood collection procedures as well as quantitative internal and external quality control procedures have been published [19]. Serum glucose, insulin, HDL -cholesterol, and triglyc eride levels were measured using the hexoquinase, chemiluminescence, enzymatic colorimetric, and enzymatic kinetic assays, respectively.
2.4. Outcome Definitions Insulin resistance markers’ definitions were based on t e following variables and equations
TyG: Ln [fasting TG (mg/dL) × fasting glucose (mg/dL)/2]
2.5. Statistical Analysis

RICA’s complex sampling design and sampling weig ts were considered in t e analyses Abso lute and relative frequencies were calculated for categorical variables. For continuous variables, normality was evaluated by the Shapiro –Wilk test. No variable had a normal distribution. Thus, medians and interquartile ranges were calculated for continuou s variables. Associations of adiposity variables with insulin resistance markers were evaluated using a multivariable regression linear model. We calculated coefficients of each independent variable stratified by age and sex. Covariates included physical i nactivity (<420 minutes of p ysical activity per week), smoking status (≥1 cigarette smoked at least one day in t e last 30 days), sedentary be avior (≥3 a day spent wit television, video games, or computer in an ordinary weekday), alcohol consumption ( ≥1 alco olic drink on at least one day in t e last 30
days), socioeconomic status (defined by whether the adolescent attended public or private schools), and Tanner stage.

Calculation of the fasting insulin equivalent (FIeq) was based on the method propose d by Sharrett AR, et al. [13]; the FIeq represented the level of fasting insulin that would replicate the strength of the association of each adiposity variable with each insulin resistance marker. In our study, following S arrett’s suggested procedure [12,13], the FIeq was calculated by dividing the beta coefficient of each adiposity measure by the fasting insulin beta coefficient from linear regression analysis. For example, the FIeq for elevated waist circumference was calculated by dividing the beta coe fficient of elevated waist circumference by the beta coefficient of fasting insulin from the linear regression analysis.

For example, in boys between 15 and 17 years old and for the outcome TG/HDL, the coefficient for the association of insulin was 0.02, w hich estimates the independent association of a 1 mU/L increase of fasting insulin with the value of TG/HDL. The coefficient for elevated WC was 0.58, and division by the insulin coefficient of 0.02 shows that the elevated WC association with TG/HDL was eq uivalent to a fasting insulin value of 29 mU/L. This value, 29 mU/L, is our estimated fasting insulin equivalent (FIeq) for WC pertaining to TG/HDL We decided not to use HOMA -IR as one of the markers of insulin resistance, as insulin was used in the model as t e “equivalent” variable and is also included in t e H MA -IR equation. All FIeq estimates and respective confidence intervals were calculated using the jackknife method (for the presentation below, all regression (beta) coefficients were rounded to two decimals places).

Due the different cut -off values of insulin resistance markers and based on the linear regression results, we conducted a secondary analysis with Poisson regression models. We used the 75th percentile value as the cut -off value of TyG an d TG/HDL.

Approximately 40% of adolescents had sedentary behavior. Most adolescents were in the pubertal stage

4. Discussion

In our study, obesity was shown to h ave stronger associations with TG/HDL and TyG in adolescents aged 12 to 14 years than in older adolescents. However, in adolescents aged 15 to 17 years, WC showed stronger associations with TG/HDL and TyG than obesity did. In a prospective study, which did not use equivalents, of 5232 children aged 9 –12 years, BMI alone was a better predictor of cardiovascular risk factors than WC was [22]. However, in another study with adolescents, WC explained a greater variance in abdominal obesity and insulin sensitivi ty than BMI percentile did [6].

Adiposity accounts for more than one -half of the variability in insulin sensitivity in normal children [23]. BMI and WC are strong surrogate measures of adiposity [24]. BMI does not distinguish between fat and muscle or bone , or consider age -related changes in body composition [25]. However, BMI has been shown to be strongly associated with X -ray absorptiometry (DXA) -determined total body fat and percent body fat in children and adolescents [26]; although, the correlation see ms to decrease in older ages [27]. WC has been found to be highly correlated with DXA fat trunk [28]. On the other hand, WC cannot satisfactorily distinguish between visceral and subcutaneous fat [29].

As a consequence of the increased release of free fatt y acid (FFA) from adipose tissue to non - adipose tissue in an insulin resistance state, there is fatty acid accumulation in non -adipose tissues, such as liver, muscle, and heart, and hypertriglyceridemia [30]. Ectopic fat deposition with lipotoxicity has be en recognized as underlying insulin resistance [30]. TG level has been shown to be negatively correlated with insulin sensitivity [31] and positively correlated with the progression of insulin secretion dysfunction [31]. Childhood obesity is related to the atherogenic lipid profile [31]. TyG index, which is a product of triglyceride and fasting glucose, was found in a previous study to be correlated with adiposity, metabolic parameters, and markers of subclinical atherosclerosis related to insulin resistanc e [9]. In adolescents with obesity, the TyG index was superior to TG/HDL and inferior to fasting insulin with the hyperinsulinemic –euglycemic clamp [9]. In a Brazilian study of adults, TyG

performed slightly better than HOMA2 -IR regarding the hyperglicemic clamp, as the outcome Visceral abdominal fat in adults is associated with insulin resistance [33]. In adults, an elevated WC is a better marker of metabolic risk than is an elevated BMI [34]. WC has been found to be more strongly correlated with TG/ HDL than BMI is in adults [35]. In adults with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus, BMI and WC were weakly correlated with TG/HDL [36]. WC appears to have a stronger correlation with TyG than BMI does in adults [37]. However, previous studies have sho wn conflicting results in children and adolescents [6,22]. In Malaysian children with obesity and overweight aged 9 through 16 years [38] and Argentinian adolescents [39], TG/HDL was found to be more strongly correlated with WC than with BMI. However, in a UK longitudinal cohort of 5000 children aged 9 –12 years, BMI was associated with cardiovascular risk factors at comparable magnitudes of association to those of fat mass and waist circumference [22].

Within our analysis using fasting insulin equivalents, TG/HDL was more strongly associated with adiposity variables than TyG was. One possible explanation is that visceral obesity contributes to insulin resistance and is also related to the dyslipidemic profile. The increased flux of free fatty acids from adip ose tissue to the liver augments hepatic triglyceride synthesis. The hepatic lipid accumulation appears to cause hepatic insulin resistance. Moreover, a low HDL cholesterol level, due to hypercatabolism of HDL in the insulin -resistant state, is more common in patients with insulin resistance than hypertriglyceridemia is [40].

Increases in body fatness, particularly adipose tissue in the abdomen of children and adolescents, is associated with abnormal lipids and insulin profiles [31,40]. In a previous study, WC alone was consistently associated with lipid concentrations in adolescents [41]. In young adults, WC, and not BMI, has shown a strong association with TG and TC/HDL cholesterol [42]. In adults, triglycerides levels are more strongly correlated with WC than with BMI. Previous studies have reported that there is an increase in serum TG concentrations from early to late adolescence [43]. In addition, there is a reduction in HDL -C concentrations, as well as an increase in TG concentrations throughout pubert al development [43]. In puberty, females have gynecoid body distribution, especially on the hips and thighs. However, males have an android body shape with excessive accumulation of abdominal fat, and relatively stable peripheral fat [44]. Adolescent boys may have more visceral abdominal fat than total abdominal adipose tissue [44,45]. Based on the fat distribution pattern, girls have more fat in the hip and less in the waist compared to boys [44]. In adults, visceral adipose tissue was more strongly associ ated with cardiometabolic risk factors than subcutaneous adipose tissue

was, independently of BMI [46]. Moreover, WC is a better predictor of visceral adipose tissue compared to BMI in children and adolescents [6]. Thus, WC measurement may be more indicati ve of insulin resistance in boys than in girls [45]. Our study suggests that WC might be more appropriate than BMI for identifying insulin resistance in late adolescence when considering specific insulin resistance markers that do not consider insulin, suc h as TG/HDL and TyG.

Limitations Our study was cross -sectional and, thus, subjected to selection/survival and temporal biases. However, survival bias has likely not occurred, given the young ages of our study sample. On the other hand, temporal bias may h ave occurred, notwithstanding the biological plausibility of our findings. In addition, despite the multivariable adjustment, as for all single observational studies, residual confounding may have occurred.

The major strengths of ERICA are its school -based , multicenter, nationwide design, rigorous quality assurance and control, and the comparison between adiposity variables and insulin resistance markers using FIeq. The study results add to previous studies that lacked a strategy for comparisons of associat ion strengths between adiposity and insulin resistance markers.
5. Conclusions

Our study suggests that WC measurements could be useful to identify adolescents with insulin resistance, particularly in late adolescence. Future studies should use a prospecti ve design and include additional insulin resistance markers, such as TyG and TG/HDL. These markers could be valuable in the early identification of insulin resistance in primary care settings. Title: Positi ve additive and multiplicative interactions among clustered components of Metabolic Syndrome with type 2 diabetes mellitus among Brazilian adolescent students
List of abbreviations and acronyms:

Aim: To evaluate additive and multiplicative interactions between pair -wise combinations of metabolic syndrome components with reg ard to type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Methods : We studied approximately 38,000 adolescents aged 12 to 17 years, sampled from a multicenter Brazilian school -based survey, The Study of Cardiovascular Risk Factors in Adolescents (Portuguese acronym, ERICA), conduc ted in 2013 –2014. Poisson regression model was used to calculate sex -, age -, obesity -, smoking status -, sedentary behavior -, physical inactivity -, alcoholic consumption - and socioeconomic status - adjusted prevalence ratios to evaluate both additive and mul tiplicative interactions. Results : In the comparison of observed and expected joint effects, relative excess risk due to additive interaction (RERI) for high triglycerides and low high -density lipoprotein -cholesterol, high triglycerides and elevated waist circumference, elevated waist circumference and low high -density lipoprotein - cholesterol and elevated waist circumference and high blood pressure were 2.53 ( -0.41, 5.46), additive interactions. Multiplicative interactions for these pairs of components were also observed, as expressed by interaction ratios >1.0. Conclusion : The joint presence of some of the components of MetS showed a greater association with the prev alence of type 2 diabetes mellitus in adolescents than expected from the sum of their isolated effects.
Keywords: metabolic syndrome, Diabetes Mellitus, biomarkers, adolescent, synergism

Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is an important public health con cern in adolescents, with a rising incidence occurring in parallel with increasing rates of childhood obesity (LIU et al., 2010) and its complications (SAVIC HITT; KATZ, 2020) , such renal disease and neuropathy (DART et al., 2014) . Defects in insulin action and re sponses are present in the early stages of diabetes (SAVIC HITT; KATZ, 2020) .

Childhood -onset T2DM is characterized by rapid progression to beta -cell failure (SAVIC HITT; KATZ, 2020) . The clinical presentation of diabetes has a broad spectrum, from mild symptoms to diabetic ketoacidosis (TFAYLI; ARSLANIAN, 2009) . Children are often diagnosed in mid to late puberty and most are obese. In T2DM’s mildest f orm, approximately one -third of children have been shown to be asymptomatic and their disease was detected by screening in the absence of typical symptomatic diabetes (REINEHR, 2005) . In addition, they usually have associated metabolic syndrome components, such as hypertension and dyslipidemia (REINEHR, 2005) .

The term Metabolic Syndrome (MetS) is used to describe a complex pathophysiological connection between risk factors for T2DM and cardiovascular disease (CVD) (ALBERTI et al., 2009; REISINGER et al., 2021) . According to the International Diabetes Federation (IDF), components of MetS are central obesity, triglycerides (TG), high -density lipoprotein - cholesterol (HDL -c), blood pressure (BP) and fasting plasma glucose (FPG) (ALBERTI; ZIMMET; SHAW, 2006) . These conditions share common pathways, mechanisms and mediators (HUANG, 2009) . Insulin resistance and central obesity are especially related to the development of MetS (ALBERTI; ZIMMET; SHAW, 2006) . Due to rising trends of obesity and overweight in adolescents (BENTHAM et al., 2017) , prevalence of MetS in adolescents are hi gh in the U.S., Middle East, and South America, particularly in Brazil and Colombia (REISINGER et al., 2021) .

There is variability in criteria used to define MetS in adolescents (MILLER et al., 2014) , which may contribute to the variability of MetS prevalence, which has ranged between 0.3% in Colombia (RAMÍREZ -VÉLEZ et al., 2016) to 26.4% in Iran (ASGHARI et al., 2017; REISINGER et al. , 2021) . Although there seems to be agreement on defining MetS components, there are differences in their cut -off points to define the syndrome. Based on a literature review conducted in 2007, there were 46 different definitions of MetS in children and a dolescents. Most of these definitions were adapted from the adult definition developed by the National Cholesterol Education Program (FORD; LI, 2008) . In a recent systematic review, the most frequen tly used definition in children and adolescents was that of the IDF (ALBERTI; ZIMMET; SHAW, 2006) , followed by those of Cook (COOK et

al., 2003) , Ford (FORD; AJANI; MOKDAD, 2005) and Ferranti (FERRANTI et al., 2004) . Whether the joint effect of the MetS components is greater than that expected based on their independent effects is controversial (KAHN et al., 2005) .

Few studies have evaluated interactions between components of metabolic syndrome with re gard to cardiovascular risk (BALDASSARRE et al., 2010; BONORA et al., 2015; FADINI et al., 2008; GOLDEN et al., 2002; INCHIOSTRO et al., 2007; VAIDYA et al., 2007) . It is important to mention that presence of additive interaction is especially rel evant to prevention and public health in general, as the disease burden in the community should be measured in absolute, not relative, excess (ROTHMAN; GREENLAND; WALKER, 1980) .

In other words, the presence of a positive additive interaction should be the framework of preventive strategies and public health policies, even when there is negative or null multiplicative interaction (SZKLO; NIETO, 2019a) . On the other hand, multiplicative interaction is preferable to assess causal relationships (VANDERWEELE; KNOL, 2014) . In the present study, the aim was to evaluate additive as well as multiplica tive interactions among combinations of metabolic syndrome components, using T2DM as the outcome.

Methods The Study of Cardiovascular Risk Factors in Adolescents (Portuguese acronym, ERICA) was a multicenter Brazilian school -based cross -sectional survey that included 75,000 adolescents aged 12 to 17 years from 1,247 schools located in 122 municipalities with ≥100,000 in abitants, conducted in 2013 -2014. This analytic sample reflected the exclusion of 4 schools that refused participation located in 2 munic ipalities (DA SILVA et al., 2016) . Among the 72,508 students in the morning shift of the total 102,327 eligible students, 37,815 adolescents from 111 municipalities had complete information on questionnai re data, anthropometrics, blood pressure and fasting blood analytes. Approximately 22% of 72,508 eligible morning shift adolescents did not answer any of the following information: questionnaire, anthropometrics, arterial blood pressure, and 24 -hour dietar y recall (DA SILVA et al., 2016) .

T e study’s multistage sampling used stratification into 32 geograp ical areas (27 State capitals and 5 macro -regions). All local Ethics Committees approved the study p rocedures. A detailed description of the study design has been published (BLOCH et al., 2015; VASCONCELLOS et al., 2015) .
Waist circumference (WC) was measured with fiber glass anthropometric tape, Sanny . As suggested by the World Health Organization, the measurement was done at the medium point

between the lower costal margin and the highest point of iliac crest (BLOCH et al., 2015) . Hig C was defined as values≥ 90t percentile for t ose aged 10 to <16 years old; and ≥ 90cm for males and ≥ 80 cm for females for t ose aged 1 6 years or older (ALBERTI; Systolic and diastolic blood pressures were measured using the automatic oscillomet ric device Omron® 705 -IT (Omron Healthcare, Bannockburn, IL, USA). The appropriate cuff size was used, with the subject sitting with their feet on the ground (BLOCH et al., 2015) , and three consecutive measures were taken with intervals of 3 minutes. The average of the 2nd and 3rd BP readings was used to reduce the impact of re activity on the BP values. High BP was defined as systolic or diastolic pressures of ≥ 130 or ≥ 85mmHg, respectively (ALBERTI; ZIMMET; SHAW, 2006) .
Biochemical assays:

Only morning shift students had their bloods collected (BLOCH et al., 2015) who, as mentioned previously, were our analytic sample. All students were instructed to fast for 12 hours the night before and blood was collected the following morning. A detailed description of blood collection procedures as well as quantitative internal and external quality control procedures have been published (CUREAU et al., 2017) . Serum glucose, insulin, HDL - cholesterol, and triglyceride levels were measured using the hexoquinase, chemiluminescence, enzymatic colorimetric and enzymatic kinetic assays, respectively. The International Diabetes Federation (IDF) MetS defi nition considered elevated WC and presence of two or more risk factors: elevated T ≥ 150mg/dl, and/or ig glucose ≥100mg/dl, and/or low HDL -c <40mg/dl for boys aged 12 -17 years and girls aged 12 -15 years or HDL -c<50mg/dl in girls aged 16 and 17 years and /or ig BP ≥130/85mmHg (ALBERTI; ZIMMET, 2007) .

T2DM was defined by diagnosed and undiagnosed diabetes. Diagnosed diabetes was identified by whether a physician had told the participants that they had diabetes and whether participants used any diabetes tr eatment recommendation. Undiagnosed diabetes was defined as glucose≥126md/dL or HbA1C ≥6.5% and wit out diabetes identified by a physician (TELO et al., 2019) . Participants who told they were using insulin classified as diabetes type 1 were excluded as the main focus of the study was T2DM.
Statistical analysis

Means and standard dev iations for continuous variables with normal distributions were calculated. For other variables, medians and interquartile ranges were calculated. Normality was evaluated by the Shapiro -Wilk test.
RICA’s complex sampling design and sampling weig ts were c onsidered in the analyses (VASCONCELLOS et al., 2015) .

Based on the definition of MetS by IDF, there were six pair -wise combinati ons for the evaluation of first order interactions, as follows: HDL -c * TG; TG * WC; HDL -c * WC; BP * WC; BP * TG and BP * HDL -c for the association with T2DM. Since impaired fasting glucose is a strong predictor of T2DM and it is included in the definitio n of the metabolic syndrome, we decided not to use the glucose component to evaluate possible interactions between metabolic syndrome components and T2DM (KAHN et al., 2005) . Our strategy to evaluate interactions was Comparison of Observed and Expected Joint Effects (SZKLO; Interaction was assessed on additive and m ultiplicative scales. While positive additive interaction is important for assessing the public health importance of an intervention, multiplicative interaction is preferable to assess causal relationships (VAND ERWEELE; We used Poisson regression models to evaluate both additive and multiplicative interactions between pair -wise clusters of metabolic syndrome components with regard to T2DM in strata formed by at least a third component, thus definin g the presence of MetS. For example, when assessing the pair -wise combination of elevated WC and high TG, we examined their 1st order interaction in stratum formed by high BP or low HDL -c, in order to meet MetS criteria. Additive interaction was measured by the Relative Excess Risk due to Interaction (RERI) (ROTHMAN, 1986) . en R RI≥0, a positive additive interaction is present. Multiplicative interaction was measured by the interaction ratio, obtained by dividing the observed joint effect by the multiplication of the independent (isolate d) effects (VANDERWEELE; KNOL, 2014). en interaction ratio (IR) ≥1, a positive multiplicative interaction is present (SZKLO; NIETO, 2019a) .

We used the delta method to calculate RERI and its 95% confidence interval (VANDERWEELE; KNOL, 2014) , the int erpretations of which were based on VanderWeele and Knol’s recommendations (VANDERWEELE; KNOL, 2014) .

Covariates included in the multivariable -adjusted regression model included age, sex, obesity (which was ba sed on age - and sex -specific BMI levels (ONIS et al., 2007) with a Z - score≥+2), p ysical inactivity (< 420 minutes per week), smoking status (≥1 cigarette smoked

at least one day in the last 30 days ), alcohol consumption (≥1 alco olic drink at least on e day in the last 30 days), sedentary be avior (≥ 3 ours a day spent wit television, video games or computer in an ordinary weekday), obesity (which was based on age - and sex -specific BMI levels (ONIS et al., 2007) with a Z -score≥+2) and socioeconomi c status (defined by whether the adolescent attended public or private schools).
All analysis was conducted using STATA version 14 (StataCorp LP, College Station, Texas).

Results As seen in Table 1, the median age was 15 years for both boys and girls, an d most adolescents were from public schools. Prevalence of unhealthy behavior varied widely from less than 5% tobacco use to 63% for physical inactivity. In addition, almost 22% of adolescents consumed at least 1 alcoholic drink in the last 30 days and app roximately 40% of adolescents had sedentary behavior. 2.6% of adolescents met the IDF criteria for MetS. Of those meeting the criteria, less than 5% had four or five components, with most adolescents having three components (Table 1). Prevalence of compon ents of metabolic syndrome in descending order were low HDL -c, elevated WC, high BP, high TG and high glucose (Table 1). Approximately 9% were obese based on age - and sex -specific BMI levels.
Approximately 3.3% had T2DM, with the majority being identified by a physician (Table 1).

Comparing observed and expected joint effects As seen in table 2, the joint effects of two metabolic syndrome components were analyzed in each stratum formed by at least a third component. In three pairs of variables, namely, T G/HDL -c, TG/WC and WC/HDL -c, the point estimates suggested interactions in both scales, however, the 95% confidence intervals overlapped the null hypothesis (Table 2). Discussion In our study, T2DM had a high prevalence of approximately 3.3%. The worldwide prevalence of T2DM in adolescents varied widely from approximately 0 to 5.1% (FAGOT -CAMPAGNA et al., 2000; FAZELI FARSANI et al., 2013; KAHKOSKA; D ABELEA, 2021; LAWRENCE et al., 2021) . According to the IDF Diabetes Atlas, the prevalence of Brazilian youth T2DM

was as high as that in indigenous American and Mexican populations (INTERNATIONAL DIABETES FEDERATION, 2021) . The ERICA study was the first school -based report in Latin America and indicates that T2DM had reached epidemic proportions in Brazilian adolescents (TELO et al., 2019) . Brazil is the fourth country in number of incident T2DM in children and adolescents (WU et al., 2022) and is the sixth country with adults living with diabetes in 2021 (SUN et al., 2022) .

Our findings suggest that TG with WC or HDL -c, and WC with HDL -c interacted positively in both scales, with 95% CIs no t overlapping the null value for the joint presence of both WC and BP. Note the fact that the 95% CIs of some additive and multiplicative indices (RERI and IR) overlap the null hypotheses (RERI=0 and IR=1.0) could be wrongly interpreted that these interactions were absent. However, as t e maximum likeli ood is t e indices’ point estimates, we prefer to say that these interactions were suggestive rather than that there were no interactions (ROTH MAN, 2014; SZKLO; NIETO, 2019b) .

Thus, in Brazilian adolescents students who meet the MetS IDF criteria, prevention of high TG with elevated WC or Low HDL -c and elevated WC with low HDL -c or high BP might result in a greater reduction in the prevalence o f T2DM than in those who only have one of t e syndrome’s components.

We found that some independent associations of MetS components with T2DM had a PR below 1.0, including low HDL -c, high BP and elevated WC. One possible explanation for these unexpected fi ndings is that the cumulative effects of each risk factor in relation to T2DM may become evident only after several years of exposure in adolescents. Thus, long latent periods of these risk factors, the independent associations of which are difficult to identify in a cross -sectional study, may explain our results (POLLOCK et al., [s.d.]) . Another possible explanation is that self -report was the main source for identification of T2DM in our study (93 %), and it is not known when diagnosis was made. Thus, adolescents with T2DM may have implemented health lifes tyle-measures, which may have resulted in attenuated prevalence ratios between risk factors and T2DM, a p enomenon known as “reverse causality” (GINSBERG; ZHANG; HERNANDEZ -ONO, 2005; LEE , S., et al., 2021) .

Another problem inherent to defin itions of of MetS is that its components are dichotomized, thus possibly resulting in loss of information, which may have decreased the likelihood of finding precise associations (ROYSTON; ALTMAN; SAUERBREI, 2006) .

Clustering of metab olic syndrome components is biologically plausible. WC is a strong marker of adiposity (JANSSEN et al., 2002) which , in addition to insulin resistance, is a key determinant of MetS (ALBERTI; ZIMMET; SHAW, 2006) . Visceral obesity contributes to

insulin resistance and is also related to a dyslipidemic profile (RADER, 2007) . The increased flux of free fatty acids (FFAs) from adipose tissue to the liver promotes an increased triglyceride synthesis in the liver. The accumulation of intracellular lipid metabolites in the liver ap pears to cause hepatic insulin resistance (RADER, 2007) . In insulin resistance setti ngs, the development of hypertension is due to loss of the vasodilator effect of insulin and the vasoconstriction caused by FFAs (TRIPATHY et al., 2003) . Additional mechanisms include increased sympathetic activation and sodium reabsorption in the kidneys (TRIPATHY et al., Our study has several strengths, including rigorous quality assurance and control. Additionally, to our knowledge, this is the largest study of MetS in adolescents based on a country -wide representative sample. Furt ermore, RICA’s large sample size allowed stratification of the MetS components for evaluation of interactions.

Our study also had some limitations. This is a cross -sectional study and, th us, subjected to both selection and temporal biases, although the representativeness of the study population and the young ages of the participants make these biases less likely. In addition, as in all observational studies, residual confounding may have o ccurred. Another potential limitation is that only two categories of MetS components were considered, thus, perhaps leading to loss of information. However, dichotomization is useful in clinical practice as it allows distinguis ing “abnormal” from “normal” results (FADINI et al., 2008) . Another limitation was that T2DM was identified mostly by self -report, likely resul ting in some degree of misclassification.

Conclusion The joint presence of high TG with elevated WC or Low HDL -c and elevated WC with low HDL -c or high BP seemed to result in both additive and multiplicative interactions with regard to T2DM in our study. Future studies should use a prospective approach and evaluate the presence of interactions in clusters of continuous components of the MetS with regard to T2DM.

8 CONSIDERAÇÕES FINAIS

Diabetes mellitus tipo 2 e resistência à insulina em adolescentes são dois importantes problemas de saúde pública, cujas prevalências vêm aumentando, conjuntamente com o aumento das prevalências de obesidade (LIU et al., 2010; REAVEN, 2004) .

A identificação da resistência à insulina em adolescentes é importante para evitar complicaçõe s futuras na vida do adolescente, como diabetes e doença cardiovascular (KOTLYAREVSKA; WOLFGRAM; LEE, 2011) . A importância da detecção da obesidade definida pelo IMC na rotina prática clínica é evide nciada nas recomendações das sociedades de pediatria e de medicina de família e comunidade (GROSSMAN et al., 2017; HASSINK et al., 2015) . Contudo, alguns estudos indicaram que a circunferência da cintura é um importante preditor de resistência à insulina (LEE , S., et al., 2006) . No primeiro artigo da tese, demonstrou -se que, usando equivalentes de insulina e m adolescentes de 15 a 17 anos, a circunferência da cintura elevada está mais fortemente associada com pode ser um melhor preditor de resistência à insulina do que o índice de massa corporal. A utilização da estratégia de Sharrett (SHARRETT et al., 2004, 2006) permitiu a comparação entre variáveis com diferentes unidades de medida, através da utilização da insulina em jejum como padrão. Nosso estudo sugere que a incorporação da medida de circun ferência de cintura pode ajudar na identificação precoce de adolescentes com resistência à insulina. No entanto, dado seu desenho seccional, estudos longitudinais devem ser realizados a fim de confirmar nossos resultados.

No segundo artigo da tese, demons trou-se a possível presença de interações positivas em algumas combinações de componentes da síndrome metabólica quando o desfecho é diabetes mellitus. Embora apenas a interação de um par de componentes não tenha incluído o valor nulo no intervalo de confi ança (CC e PA), as interações, particularmente as aditivas, podem ser de ajuda na definição de grupos de alto risco para prevenção do diabetes pois priorizar adolescentes com essas combinações pode resultar em uma redução mais acentuada da prevalência de d iabetes mellitus do que em adolescentes que têm apenas um componente da síndrome metabólica.

Em relação a resistência à insulina, novos estudos de desenho longitudinal são necessários, incluindo marcadores de resistência à insulina. Esses marcadores pode m ser vantajosos para identificação de resistência à insulina no ambiente da atenção primária.
